text:
A non-Julia advice but I believe people can guide better:-

I want to get into data science but the maths(stats and prob) confuses me a lot. I have theoretical knowledge instead of practical knowledge 

I know little bit of stats from school but there's a serious disconnect in applicability of that Maths in real world problem solving 

Also, I don't want to study data science from engineer's point of view 

I want to learn to learn data science from a marketing or sales  point of view....so I can solve real world marketing and sales problems for companies 

I'm confused where should I start learning Maths for data science. I don't want to study masters in DS(can't afford it also not a fan of college education). I have couple of math resources in mind(3blue1brown, khan academy, open stax stats and business books)

I'm literally confused where to begin with and my what would my complete learning journey look like?

text: Im a little confused, you say you have theoretical knowledge, but say that the math confuses you a lot. What exactly do you mean by that?

elements.text: Im a little confused, you say you have theoretical knowledge, but say that the math confuses you a lot. What exactly do you mean by that?

text:
I mean I know what Bayes' theorem is. I can solve text books problems

But there's huge disconnect when it comes to applying that with real world problems

text: What was your undergraduate degree in? Bayes' theorem is really the tip of the iceberg...

elements.text: What was your undergraduate degree in? Bayes' theorem is really the tip of the iceberg...

text: honestly the best advice in this regard that has been given to me is pick a problem and solve it. The goal is not to solve the problem but to understand how you solved and why it works. You can go as deep as you are comfortable.

elements.text: honestly the best advice in this regard that has been given to me is pick a problem and solve it. The goal is not to solve the problem but to understand how you solved and why it works. You can go as deep as you are comfortable.

text: I know that sounds too abstract but the secret sauce is that while doing this the biggest thing I learned was what to google/read. I didn't know how regularization actually worked till I saw it in action and played around with the algorithm (god I wish pluto was around back then)

elements.text: I know that sounds too abstract but the secret sauce is that while doing this the biggest thing I learned was what to google/read. I didn't know how regularization actually worked till I saw it in action and played around with the algorithm (god I wish pluto was around back then)

text: <@U015QHEJX2Q> languages don't matter if you are not looking at how things are actually computed. For example if you are learning how to do linear regressions you can study the maths or get lost in the details of how they efficiently do this computation. I am guilty of doing this and have been actively working on it. So, I guess my advice is remember is not python, its just pseudo code where only the equations are important.

elements.text: languages don't matter if you are not looking at how things are actually computed.
